courseDescription: Provides training in theories of intelligence and psychometric properties, administration, scoring and interpretation of major individually administered intelligence tests for children, adolescents and adults.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with clients during testing process
Explaining test results to clients and stakeholders
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Providing leadership in test interpretation and decision-making

courseDescription: Using a social psychological framework, the course covers theories such as interpersonal expectancies/behavioral confirmation, prejudice and discrimination, social inclusion, social cognition, and attitudes/attitude change.  The research evidence for these theories and how these social psychological constructs influence or impede the mental health process will also be considered.  This course will also allow students to research and critically analyze conceptual and theoretical foundations for providing psychological services across diverse cultural populations.
Technical and Digital Skills: Data analysis in social psychological research
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Presenting research findings in a culturally sensitive manner
Effective communication with individuals from diverse cultural backgrounds
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical analysis of social psychological theories and research findings
Identifying and addressing biases in research on multicultural issues
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading and facilitating discussions on multicultural and social psychological topics
Organizing and managing research projects with diverse teams

courseDescription: This course covers topics related to the physical, cognitive, social and emotional aspects of growth, from conception to death.  It focuses on human growth and development, but other organisms are also considered.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of growth and development stages
Ability to analyze physical, cognitive, social, and emotional aspects of growth
Research skills in human and organism development
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaboration with peers on research projects related to growth and development
Presentation of findings on human growth and development topics
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of growth and development information
Identification of patterns in developmental data
Problem-solving in understanding human and organism growth processes
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing research materials on human growth and development
Leading group discussions on growth and development theories and research

courseTitle: Clinical Assessment: Personality and Individual Differences
courseDescription: This course covers history of personality theory and assessment, and psychometrics, and introduces tools and techniques aimed at understanding individual differences in personality and assessment of major psychopathology.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication of assessment results to clients
Building rapport with patients during assessment

courseDescription: Introduces basic therapy skills to clinical psychology students and explores the ethical framework which guides the profession.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Empathy and rapport building with clients
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Ethical dilemma resolution in therapy practice
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Supervision and mentorship of junior staff

courseDescription: Examines the history and systems of psychology related to contemporary applied psychology.
Technical and Digital Skills: Analyzing historical data in psychology research
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaborating with peers on research projects
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of historical psychological theories
Identifying patterns in historical psychological trends
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading group discussions on historical psychology topics

courseDescription: This course will cover research design and methodology.  Topics may include experimental, quasi-experimental, single subject and survey research; validity; reliability; psychometric theory; confounds; measurement; sampling; inductive inference.  Additionally, this course will cover Responsible Conduct of Research, including completion of CITI course, protection of human subjects, University Human Subjects Committee and IRB, APA Style, paper structure, references, tables, figures, etc., research proposal writing, including searching for sources, writing, oral presentation, data collection and management issues (e.g., Qualtrics, SONA, data cleaning).  Students are required to complete a Research Proposal with Introduction and Methods and Data Analysis Plan and give an oral presentation of research proposal.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaboration with University Human Subjects Committee and IRB
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identification and mitigation of confounds in research

courseDescription: The course covers issues relevant to diverse populations to enhance student development of cultural humility and improved cultural competence in clinical practice. The course reviews conceptual and theoretical foundations as well individual and systemic influences that contribute to mental health.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of systemic influences on mental health
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of cultural influences on mental health
Analyzing individual and systemic factors affecting mental health outcomes

courseDescription: Covers theory and techniques of cognitive and behavioral approaches. Applications for assessment and treatment of adults, children, couples and families are discussed.

courseTitle: Analysis of Variance and Experimental Design
courseDescription: Review of the basic descriptive and inferential statistical procedures with a heavy emphasis on fundamental and advanced analysis of variance techniques.  Topics include contrasts, factorial designs, within-subject and mixed designs, and analysis of covariance.  Course materials are covered in the context of classical experimental and quasi-experimental design.

Course covers correlation with heavy emphasis on regression analysis in the context of the general linear model.  Topics include partial correlations, categorical and continuous interactions, non-linear regression, and multivariate statistics.  Course materials are covered in the context of correlational designs and survey research.

This course is designed to introduce students to the field of program evaluation as well as to give students practical experience conducting a program evaluation.  Students will get experience creating and conducting qualitative and quantitative assessments.  A course goal is to work in small groups to conduct a program evaluation.

This course introduces classical test theory, including definitions and equations for test reliability, standard error of measurement, and related statistics.  Additional topics include scaling, item statistics useful in test constructions, norms commonly used in educational and psychological testing, test validity and exploratory factor analysis.  If time permits, Item Response (IRT) and Generalizability Theory are introduced.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Explaining complex statistical concepts to non-experts
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying item statistics for test construction

courseDescription: This course covers the topics of linear structural equation modeling and focuses on estimation, measurement models, confirmatory and hierarchical factor analysis, structural equations, longitudinal models, multisample analyses, and mean structures.

courseTitle: Social and Affective Bases of Behavior
courseDescription: This course discusses the behavior of the human as a member of a group and the experience and expression of emotion. Topics include attitude theory and change, interpersonal attraction, stereotypes and discrimination, social cognition and social affect, aggression, theories of emotion and emotion regulation.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding group behavior in social settings
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing group activities related to emotions
Leadership in group settings for behavior analysis

courseDescription: Study of selected topics in clinical psychology.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaborating with fellow researchers in data analysis
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Developing research hypotheses based on data
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading research projects in clinical psychology
Organizing research data effectively for analysis

courseDescription: Study of selected topics in clinical psychology.

Empirically-Supported Therapies is designed to foster the integration of clinical science and the practice of psychotherapy. Course objectives include learning how to identify, evaluate, and implement empirically supported interventions for various psychological disorders.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Developing treatment plans based on empirical evidence
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading a team of therapists in implementing evidence-based practices

courseDescription: Individual research project under guidance of a research advisor.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaboration with peers in research projects
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying research gaps and proposing solutions

courseTitle: Biological and Cognitive Aspects of Behavior
courseDescription: This course provides an integrative overview of how brain structure and functioning produces behavior and cognition in both normal and clinical contexts.  Students learn gross neuroanatomy and physiology of the nervous system (primarily central), a working knowledge of functional neuroanatomy, and how the central nervous system functions in an integrated fashion.  Students also learn the basics of brain-behavior relationships and how these present normally and in clinical cases in order to gain a general and broader understanding of cognitive processes.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of brain structure and functioning
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying brain-behavior relationships in clinical cases

courseDescription: The course is designed: (1) to teach students to write article-length scholarly manuscripts in APA format of publishable quality, and (2) to teach students the critical components of grant applications.  By the end of this course, each student will have prepared a manuscript that is ready for submission to a peer-reviewed journal and have completed sections of a federal grant application.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaboration with peers for manuscript improvement
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Developing innovative research ideas for grants
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading research teams for grant applications

courseDescription: This course focuses on contemporary theory and research topics in health psychology. The course examines psychological and behavioral issues affecting health maintenance, coping with life-threatening illnesses and chronic diseases, and health promotion. The course uses the biopsychosocial (mind-body) model as an organizing framework, emphasizing the dynamic interactions among biological, social, personality, and behavioral factors jointly in influencing people's health. The course is conducted as a seminar.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying behavioral factors affecting health outcomes
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Coordinating research projects in health psychology

courseDescription: Social science data frequently have a hierarchical or multilevel structure as a consequence of sampling designs or repeated measures. The purpose of the course is to introduce students to the basic principles and applications of hierarchical linear modeling in social science research. Topics covered include an introduction to multilevel analyses, random intercept models, random slope models, hypotheses testing, hierarchical models for limited dependent variables, model fitting, three-level models, and repeated-measures applications.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Hierarchical models for limited dependent variables

courseDescription: This course is designed to introduce students to the field of program evaluation as well as to give students practical experience conducting a program evaluation.  Students will get experience creating and conducting qualitative and quantitative assessments.  A course goal is to work in small groups to conduct a program evaluation.

This course covers the topics of linear structural equation modeling and focuses on estimation, measurement models, confirmatory and hierarchical factor analysis, structural equations, longitudinal models, multisample analyses, and mean structures.

courseTitle: Social and Affective Bases of Behavior
courseDescription: This course discusses the behavior of the human as a member of a group and the experience and expression of emotion. Topics include attitude theory and change, interpersonal attraction, stereotypes and discrimination, social cognition and social affect, aggression, theories of emotion and emotion regulation.
Technical and Digital Skills: Data analysis in social science research
Statistical analysis of social behavior data
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of social behavior theories
Identifying and addressing stereotypes and discrimination in social contexts
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading group discussions on social psychology topics
Organizing research projects in social behavior analysis

courseDescription: Individual project under guidance of a research advisor.
Pre-doctoral internship in clinical psychology.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Confidentiality and ethics adherence in communication
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Supervision and mentorship of junior staff

courseDescription: 1-6 credits each semester for variable credit.

Student assigned to a clinical practice setting to learn the skills of a clinical psychologist under close supervision. Various mental health settings through southeastern Virginia are used for this experience.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Team coordination in a clinical setting

courseDescription: Student assigned to a practice setting to be given an opportunity to learn the advanced skills of a clinical psychologist under close supervision. Various mental health settings throughout the area are used.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Diagnosis formulation based on assessment findings
Treatment planning and intervention selection based on evidence-based practices
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Case management and coordination of care
Supervision and mentorship of junior clinicians

courseDescription: Student works with research mentor to develop, write, and defend an empirical dissertation.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Mentorship and guidance of research assistants

courseDescription: Provides a theoretical and practical introduction to the work of leaders in mental health settings, addressing managerial and clinical supervision and various models of consultation.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with team members and clients
Conflict resolution in a clinical setting
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Problem-solving in clinical and managerial scenarios
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Team leadership in mental health settings

courseDescription: Research related to doctoral dissertation.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Presentation of research findings to peers and faculty

courseDescription: This course is a pass/fail course doctoral students may take to maintain active status after successfully passing the candidacy examination. All doctoral students are required to be registered for at least one graduate credit hour every semester until their graduation.
